If you need to quickly fill of your tummy before heading to one of the neighbouring clubs/pubs/bars, this is definitely a place you should pop in to.The Bibimbap comes along with Gochujang and Doenjang sauces with the former being made from red chili peppers and the later being white bean. You can make your Bibimbap spicier by adding Gochujang. The Korean Hite beer is also worth trying. The servers were neither very attentive nor friendly on a busy Saturday evening but it didn't bother much.

Bf2Xit7GZuz6XEpyVDeo9w.text: I went because of a friend but I really wasn't up for it. Although the restaurant had pretty good reviews, I really didn't know if I was going to like it... And oh my, was I wrong! I love the decor, I love the people, they are very very sweet! And the food is so tasty. I had a spicy chicken ramen the first time which was just delicious!! And the second time I had another dish with chicken which was also really tasty! For the price you pay, you will have big portions that will, I promise, keep you very satisfied! I'm sure you'll love it!

_fvmSQVJrpSAHpVCrl3SRg.text: Amazing!! I went twice and I had the bibimbap with spicy pork and with spicy chicken + fried egg. Super tasty, served well in warm bowl. Service was quick but arrive early for lunch to get a table, its so good it gets crowded post 12.15-12.30 !

1YpWGEr1-Cg0YEug2BhMCQ.text: They made us wait for a long time before taking our order. Actually, I had to flag them down.The food was alright, I got some stone bowl stuff, but the rice at the bottom of the bowl was burned and really stiff. That kind of made it less good.Would I come here again? Perhaps, but only if I were in the area and everything else happened to be closed or full.

bfz1U9Ny9yhMjouG4xmohA.text: My boyfriend and I had been wandering around London, starving, trying to find something that was both within our price range and not sketchy-looking. I was so excited when we found this place (though I would have eaten anything by that point)! It had been a few months since I'd had one of my favourite dishes, bibimbap. It was great! The interior was really cute & bright. Would go back again.

qP7237-W8NvFt_uaH6RATw.text: Very good dol sot bibimbap!  Quick service as well.  They also have Hite beer and some other Korean foods on tap.

0D4Z4SsbzrV8--UEJVsxzQ.text: Haven't had a  Bibimbap before. Wikipedia says it's a signature Korean dish that means mixed meal. Warm rice with seasoned vegetables, some chili paste and some meat. Bi Bim Bap serves the variant that comes in a very hot stone bowl that sizzles the contents as you stir it around.I liked the concept and the food was great. Good combination of flavours. You can also add egg as an extra which would cook as you stir it (I didn't get that option but would like to try next time).A great little place in the middle of Soho for a quick meal and no queue for a table on a Friday night - bonus for that.Service was efficient. Simple, utility designed interior which was good and importantly good value - especially for Soho.Two bibimbaps and two drinks, £21 including service.

qS-zRe_T4eiUKxwI4yNucQ.text: This is place is great. Exactly what you expect, really nice meat (I had the beef, piping hot (the bowl is literally burning when they serve it), great brown rice, really nice vegetables and a delicious fried egg on top. Perfect portion sizes too. Great for a quick lunch.

9BTLA1aW04usORVHCH4FQw.text: We came here on a Friday night, after drinks, looking for a good meal.  We walked along Greek Street and happened upon this place, which looked appealing as we hadn't had Korean for a while.We both had a bi-bim-bap (mine with pork, my partner's with beef).  They were fine (tasty and spicy) but I missed the crispy "crust" of rice you get on the bottom of the pot when it all works right.

pN18dWDs-6tYrprvENCGKg.text: I went to Bi Bim Bap for the first time a couple of weeks ago with a big group of friends and everyone loved it. I had the traditional Dol Sot which was spot on with a perfectly fired egg on top, chopped and mix through the rice and vegetables with both Chilli and miso sauce!!! YUM. Another favourite of the group was the fillet beef Bi Bim Bap that arrives with raw strips of beef that cook in the hot stone bowl in a matter of seconds when you start mixing.This place is a MUST visit and I would recommend to anyone looking for something a bit different in Soho.ENJOY!

ICt-EKxsLGKWSKkrOVNX2w.text: Bibimbap was A-OK.  Price good, portion size good, service good.  However, it was a bit too greasy for me (I have a feeling that this was to counteract food sticking to the stonepot), and very very salty.  So perhaps it isn't the health food it advertises itself as?I am reluctant to give it more than three stars because I was totally disappointed towards the bottom of the bowl.  Having ordered bibimbap at a few other places, generally there's this delicious layer of crispy rice at the bottom.  I don't know Korean food well enough to know if this is authentic, or a bastardised version to Western tastes, but it's my favourite part of the whole dish!  And it was lacking!Oooo... and don't bother ordering the kimchi.  It's good, but for three small pieces at 1.50, it's best to just pop round to the local Korean supermarkets in the area.

0MDFelAcrfVQiILHRLATlw.text: Bi Bim Bap is one of those cheap and cheerful joints in Soho where you can get a really good meal for 10 quid.  The name of the restaurant stands for their main specialty dish - bibimbap which means mixed rice.  This is the first time I've been to an all bibimbap restaurant that offers so many options and varieties to a standard staple korean dish.  I ordered the spicy pork bibimbap and happy to slather it with chilli sauce in the ketchup like bottle.  It's the perfect quick meal to have in the winter time as it's pipin' hot and spicy.  I find that good authentic Korean food hard to come by in the UK so this place nearly brought a tear to my eye.

8tR8HA_nucJoRPKZ4KdNCg.text: It looks like  good reviews from English or residents in London?? But it was very disappointing food, price and service for me as a American. Plum wine is way too expensive (18 £) , 3 starters - jab chae, tofu and sea food pancake - were in small tiny dishes, not interesting flavor in bibimbaps-nutritious, salmon and beef. No side dishes at all like kimchi and charged for a fried egg. It was a busy day but Service was not fast or nice.Oh my!

onQiM77Vhk_uXjIqmZQ8MQ.text: Solid.Went here for my birthday with a bunch of bi bim bap virgins. They all loved it. I LIKED it, but to be honest, I'll keep searching for better bbb in London.Like others have said, not as crispy on the bottom, the service (even for London) less than stellar, and I wish they were less stingy with the Kim Chee, which I thought was a bit overpriced for the size.But, you know, filling, decent meal for under £10, so if you're in the area, give it a try.And if any of you know of an AWESOME bbb place, please message me asap.

0PZ0TyjlUjvhZqsZSggeaA.text: so delicious bi bim bap there, the best i have ever eat! my salad bi bim bap was so tasty:much veggies (love) and this holy marinated chicken (miss it)the guy seemed to be very annoyed when i asked whether he could explain what bi bim bap would be last but not least the waitress forced us to go immediately after we had paid, that was not very charming.okay new guests came in but i prefer to sit and relax after dining a bit.all in all i just don like the service that much.

JAb8wVdE1rHnbEGLT5GX9g.text: Love the food and great service. We ordered the spicy kimchi beef tofu soup and bulgogi beef and both dishes were delicious! Highly recommended! Will definitely come back when in town again!

nOUHUBeFlapnK37h7yLUMQ.text: Have been a big fan of Korean food for a long time and this restaurant in food terms did not disappoint. I ordered a fillet beef Bi Bim Bap which was superb and extremely tasty. The Kim Chi Pancakes which I also had as a side were a welcome complement to the meal and really added to the whole taste. My partner had a Beef Bi Bim Bap with Dumplings which she also found to be excellent.The only issue I would have with the place was the drinks menu, which was a little limited and the atmosphere was slightly quiet, although this could be due to the fact that it was a Wednesday night.Overall a very enjoyable experience and I definitely intend to go back.

I7A8tFJ1Va6hUzkMEwspNQ.text: Love this place! The Polaroids and Kpop add to the atmosphere, and the service was excellent they gave us regular updates while in the queue on how long it would be (wasn't that long and totally worth the wait) and were lovely when we gave very confusing orders. I had a classic beef bool go gi, I must admit this was partly because I liked the name and wanted to say it out loud. I upgraded to having brown rice and a fried egg on top which led to the complicated ordering as we all changed our order after making them to include a few extras - out waitress was lovely about it though and we all still got exactly what we ordered and she had remembered who had ordered what. The food was delicious!! It explains on the menu that the trick is to mix everything up really well and who doesn't love being encouraged to play with their food? This leads to amazing flavour combinations, and each bite being unique. You can taste the freshness of the ingredients and it is great to be able to cook anything more on the bowl, if you want to, and it is a bonus that you can eat slowly and still have the food piping hot all the way to the bottom of the bowl. The bill was another pleasant surprise, really good value.I will definitively be back- and if anyone knows how you get a Polaroid on the wall please let me know!

3mHhUg1VEA28BbmwlKbH2Q.text: The food isn't terrible but it's certainly not the best Bi Bim Bap out there. The polaroids are cute and the servers pretty friendly. If you are getting Bibimbap, the beef bulgogi is good along with a fried egg. Not sure why but quite a few people eating in here don't mix the bowl of food together. It's worth a good mix, both to experience the traditional way of eating the hot rice bowl, and to make sure your rice doesn't end up stuck to the bottom of your hot stone. May be worth avoid the soups as they tend to pretty salty.

ybJW_r6n2JiqIVhoUPQivQ.text: After reading some of the other reviews about this place I was intrigued as I have never had Korean food before. It is just something that had slipped under the radar that is, until now. So I decided to seek this place out and try one of their signature dishes the famed bibimbap. I went for what I considered to be  a safe option and ordered the Beef Bool Go Gi. Basically what came out was a stone bowl filled with rice and topped with a heap of delicious ingredients including some succulent marinated beef strips. Mix it all together and start eating, unbelievable.  I saw some people with an egg on top of their order but I wasn't brave enough, maybe next time. I recommend this restaurant to anyone who wants an introduction to Korean.

CABdu_MKYxScSsAyXdRxRw.text: I was oh-so-excited when my friend suggested Bimbimibap. The first time I tried bimbimibap was in a  Korean restaurant in Nottingham, and it was one of the best things I'd ever tasted. On this menu, I was excited to see several vegetarian options. I opted for the classic, which the restaurant's logo is based on. It was certainly pretty, but didn't taste of much. I added quite a lot of the available sauce, and even then the dish felt a little bland. I doubt I'll be returning.

photos.caption: Photo of Bibimbap - London, United Kingdom. The classic  (with raw egg substituted for fried egg)

17tp_Dmm3B8Xd9esrVXKog.text: HOT RICE SIZZLING IN A BOWL. What's not to love?! It's a regular haunt of mine so, I usually take Korean food virgins here, it's a nice way to ease them in, without smelling like a KBBQ house when you walk out the door. ALTHOUGH, that smell is sometimes very delicious. LOLThey offer so many choices. my two favourites are definitely the mixed mushroom with brown rice or the yukwhe dolsot bibimbap. I prefer the former because when they bring it out with the raw egg, raw meat in the bowl. Some people get well freaked out, and it's funny. Well I think it's funny. It's a cute place, it's got polaroids of customers along the walls, and it's playing korean pop in the background. so, the bibimbap's are not the best in the world, for me, but the choice makes up for it.

aKMYjtamq4idtUKvs7EGsA.text: Yum Yum Yum. This is my first experience with bi bim bap and what a wonderful experience it was. Holy mazing. On the healthier and cheaper side of eating out in the city, the beef bool-go-gi is a incredible mass of meat over veggies and rice (option of brown rice) that cooks in a hot stone bowl as you eat it! It can come with a fried egg on top as well if you like.  I can still hear the sizzling deliciousness in my food coma dreams. They serve this all with two sauces: a red chili and a miso. The miso was to die for and I made sure to savor and close my eyes with every bite that touched my tongue.I love Kim Chi so I also decided to try out the pancakes as a previous reviewer had recommended and I was not disappointed with the flavor or taste. However, it was a bit on the richer side food-wise for me so next time I think I would just order the plain Kim Chi. (But really there is more than enough food already in the main course without needing to order any additions.) This place is so tasty that I have now converted my usually very finicky eating boyfriend to the delicious ways of Korean food and I think he very well may become a regular here. I also can not say enough about how lovely and accommodating the people who worked there were. They made sure to open and close the door for us as we came and went and checked up on us to make sure we were enjoying our meal. Obviously I have nothing bad to say about this establishment so get your butt off the sofa and into Soho and give it a try.

photos.caption: Photo of Bibimbap - London, United Kingdom. Next time I will make sure to take a prettier picture of my beef bi bim bap when it is in its true perfect form.
Photo of Bibimbap - London, United Kingdom. The Kim Chi Pancake and Fried Squid
Photo of Bibimbap - London, United Kingdom. Wall of photos at Bi Bim Bap

w3hc7Lrns8XkjkxboyXTGQ.text: I had found this place after looking on Trip Advisor and Yelp and placed it in our "possible" places to eat. We were looking at another location while in Soho and passed this. It smelled delicious from the outside and decided we would return later in the week to try it. We did and what a pleasant surprise! You order your dinner which is placed in incredibly hot stone bowls (the tables bear the marks of the heat which goes through the wooden place settings it is placed on). You are then given two different sauces to add if you want (one is like a Miso and the other like a Sriracha). Spicy even without the add ins, the food is beyond delicious. As you eat the bowls remain hot so you can stir the food up and the cooler food goes to the bottom and side where it warms up again and the warmer food comes to the top. The food never gets cold, Great concept. You can opt out of the egg on top or mix it in. We saw two customers piling on the sauces, and I as a lover of spice, choked just looking at the amount - they had to have lead lined stomachs. talking to our daughter, she was very familiar with this Korean bowl style and has eaten it before and knew the whole process. Why didn't you ever mention it before? So impressed. we are now in the process of looking for similar stone bowls so we can try to recreate a similar dish at home.

f1RB5yDlXxeJjM3BUcJe0Q.text: Looking for something healthy? Light? Full of veggies? Then, this is the place to go!Most all dishes are less than 10 GBP, which I suppose is pretty cheap and reasonable here in London.**The rice is not crispy, like someone else noted. However, this is not a typical old-fashioned Korean restaurant. It's a more modern-day, "express" (if you will), Korean Bi-bim-bap (BBB) restaurant. So, the pot is hot, but the rice is not crispy. So, what does this place do differently? Well, most everything is similar to other places. However, they have TWO sauces: "chili" sauce and "miso" sauce. The "chili" sauce is really a red pepper paste-based sauce, really not very spicy. The miso sauce is like ... miso sauce (or to me, it tasted like doen-jang, which is a korean soy bean paste -- regardless, very similar to miso). I enjoyed the miso and was pleasantly surprised. I used BOTH of them (extra miso, please)! I ordered the FILET BEEF BBB. The filet meat is served raw!!! The server mentioned that this was his favorite. When I got the plate, he was not joking! I looked at the raw strips of meat, and I second guessed whether I should have ordered something that was already cooked. However, he was right. The meat DID in fact cook while I was mixing it. So, that was reassurring.***the ONE thing I wish would have happened differently: I wish they would've told me that they charge extra for a fried egg on top of the BBB. The "extras" may have noted it, but I wasn't looking for it. Anyway, other than that, I was pleased.SEATING: One very long bar that seats about 10 (individuals, this is probably where you'll sit, but the gazillion pictures makes it quite exciting!). There were a handful of tables up front that seat 2 and 4, a couple in the back, a booth, and there may have been some seating downstairs -- not sure about the downstairs!

photos.caption: Photo of Bibimbap - London, United Kingdom. Filet beef Dol Sot BBb

bYAU9OPBP982loK03x6vEQ.text: I found Bi Bim Bap in the Cheap Eats section of Time Out Magazine. The pimp hand of the pound is strong, and I could only take so many wallet lashings per day. I have been a lover of Korean food since 2001, when my college roomie first introduced me to it. We spent many a late night eating rice or kimchi instead of the standard college pizza delivery. So, I'm always down for some Bi Bim Bap! When I invited my uncle to meet me there for dinner, he jokingly asked me if I was the Skat Man and I was singing a song. Luckily for him, he was about to get educated in the ways of fast and delicious Korean delights. We were seated immediately at a booth. For appetizers, we started with the spicy rice cakes and the seafood pancakes. (My mouth is literally watering just thinking about it...) I ordered the Beef Bool-Go-Gi Bi Bim Bap. In the U.S., I normally get the Dol Sot Bi Bim Bap (served in a hot stone bowl) and that normally comes with beef. But, here, I had to get the beef added on. The quality of the meat was great. It wasn't too thinly sliced and was very well seasoned. Overall, the food was delicious and well priced. Go there, if you are in Bloomsbury and in need of some noms that will leave you with some coinage. With your left over cash money, you can head over to Covenant garden and get some souvenirs. You're welcome.

qSqX58s-uXT6KkUbxxkZqw.text: Everytime I've been I've had the traditional Bi Bam Bap, which is served in a cast iron dish and cooks before your eyes. The food is very tasty and they have few different options for the Bi Bam Bap, there are also noodle and salad dishes available and a selection of sides. The dish comes with two sauce bottles, miso and spicy.  You get chopsticks and a spoon to eat it as it can be quite tricky to use the chopsticks when you can't touch the bowl.My only complaint is I always go when I'm quite hungry and as the food is cold in the bowl I can never wait long enough for it to heat up fully.  Also I could do with a bit more food as I'm still hungry afterwards. Definitely a place to go for a quick bite to eat if you are in the central London area.

_8xopTpDMjIYlm-2ACFmWA.text: I love good dolsot bibimbap, and for £8.95, you can have a delicious one.For those who don't know what bibimbap is, it's basically a variety of toppings on a bed of rice in a hot stone pot. You can order a fried egg for a pound more to add even more flavor, and you stir and swirl it all for just...amazing heaven.I love the fact that the waitress provided me with two sauces: gochujang (spicy) and soy bean (non-spicy). I believe she told me the soy bean was miso-based. SO GOOD.My only bummer is that while the dish itself is hot (as I burned tongue a few times), it's not hot enough where you can get crunchy bits of rice at the bottom. That's the best part about eating bibimbap!

r6V5bcWtqpHB50bj2qmhHw.text: Man I love BiBimBap. I could eat there any time I am around Soho. I end up there maybe once every two months, if not more. I don't want to OD on it. Sometimes I just day dream I was nearby to get a big ol' sizzlin' rice bowl! Oh sweet chilli sauce o' mine! YUM!As mentioned before, the service can be all over the place. But it doesn't stop me from returning. I bring new people every time I go and they all fall in love with the food as well. It's great for families, friends, omnivores or vegans; everyone! Try the Korean beer Hite (Save yourself some embarrassment, friends; it's pronounced like "height", not hee-tay) or the loose teas are lovely on a cool day.For the starters the dumplings are nice, but nothing fancy. I would go for the steamed tofu or kim chi. Mains are always difficult. I steer newcomers away from the comfort of noodles to their signature dishes of bibimbap. It's their name sake for Pete's sake! What are they thinking!? Now, do I want spicy kimchi? The textural wonderland of the "Nutritious" bowl and those lovelt ginko nuts? Mushrooms? Mounds and mounds of mushrooms!? Chewy fried tofu? I'm seriously drooling here. Top it off with some mild chilli sauce and miso sauce, awww, Heaven! Now get your metal spoons ready to stir!!Now, they do not give you a traditional raw egg on top (food laws I think), but you may be able to ask for it if they think you know what you are doing.(After a full belly, we usually pop across the street to Lick for a cheeky sample of gelato.)They used to take your group's photo to put on the wall, does anyone know if they still do? January was the last time mine was taken.

DJ2sYtXQBT2-YYtXjHNDIQ.text: Stumbled upon this place while looking for a place to eat on a Friday night--eekk, in Soho ? ! not the best idea..alas, there was a short queue (5 min) and we were seated.  The service was fast & good..and the food comes out fast so if it's a date --forget the small talk! Food was great, filling & affordable, I'll be back !

7Zg5bxJAPnbz86dQgnl9qQ.text: Had the katsu prawn, chilli squid, brown rice, seafood pancake and the Korean fried chicken. I love Korean food and was slightly disappointed with this place, portions were way too small for the price and I think my biggest disappointment was the seafood pancake. It was bland, small and did not look fresh. The chicken pieces were beyond small it was ridiculous. The remaing food: chilli squid, prawns and brown rice were good. I won't be coming back though.

u4cT67LSR-lTffWreIpJmQ.text: Bi Bim Bap seafood and vegetables-egg dishes were delicious. Baked kimchi pancake starter was tasty too. We enjoyed the food while drinking Korean green tea. The service was very friendly and they quickly found us a free table even we didn't make a reservation. It's to mention that many good Soho restaurants are in late evening crowded and customers have to wait outside till a table get free. The prices are cheap which is not to expect by a good Soho restaurant. It was really a high quality food.

photos.caption: Photo of Bibimbap - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bibimbap - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bibimbap - London, United Kingdom

oABjiF8Y-nHDT6OllA-kug.text: I called to reserve for a table but unfortunately they don't take bookings unless it is for a huge group.For a Tuesday night, it was pretty busy. However I can imagine how busy it would be on a Friday or Sat night. Their Jap Chae was amazing. It was literally the best one we've had and we have all been to several Korean restaurants. Too bad the portion is small, yes I know it is only a starter! We also tried 4 other starters and all ordered the same bibimbap (yummy). What you're paying is pretty good for quality & quantity.I'd highly recommend anyone to go if they have a craving for Korean without forking out a fortune! :)

5p9a0efHCm30MNYhEj6Skg.text: First time trying bibimbap, and I really enjoyed it! I had the dol sot bibimbap, which is their classic. It comes with cucumber, daikon, bean sprouts, spinach, carrots, mooli, and a fried egg on top. It was tasty, healthy (I got brown rice for a slight extra charge), and cheap. My kind of food! I noticed some complaints in other reviews about small portion size, but I didn't find this was the case. I have a big appetite, and my bowl filled me up just fine.

GoQz18dSFR-127jCG2UfEQ.text: Two stars lost here but not because the food is mediocre, because some of the rules regarding service defy logic and the staff seem a little manic and insane. Since all the Korean places by Centre Point got ripped down and fucked by central London redevelopment, this probably is the best place to have Koreas best dish that they serve in a sizzling stone pot. I came here in a group of 4 last Friday and tried to get a table. One of our party was outside having an important phone call with his grandad, so we went in to secure a table. The woman on the door told us this wouldn't be possible, despite the restaurant being largely empty. We asked if we could get a drink in the meantime, in which were told yes but would have to stand by the doorway to drink it. Very bizarre, seeing as there was a completely empty sideboard running down the restaurant with approximately 12 empty seats. Maybe we should have said that we would be willing to move should a party of 12 eye contact fearing people, who insist on sitting in a row next to each other arrive during the 5 minutes we had to wait for our friend to finish his phone call, but we were too baffled by the logic at play to ask questions. We went back outside and seriously debated wether to fuck it off and go to Wetherspoons, but in the end we went back fully grouped. Other than the demented work of the staff, I have little else to say except the food was quite good. The Kimchi pancake was light and sponge-like and the egg and beef in my bibimbap was raw like I asked for, served in a sizzling bowl as you would expect. I'm making it sound more functional that it was, but really the rest of the bullshit kind of overshadowed the deliciousness of the food which is a huge shame for everyone involved here. Without wanting to be patronising, I feel like for the bibimbap novices out there I should say NEVER get precooked beef or fried egg on top unless you can eat the whole thing in 2 seconds or like leathery beef and chalky dry egg yolks. And if you do, then I want absolutely nothing to do with you - fuck off!!!!!!

ULE0QEFt1oDqPr-n3YGucQ.text: I've wanted to go to this place for ages. We went on a Monday and as is everywhere in Soho it was busy. This unfussy and informal place is great-there's a long bench for single diners (why can't more restaurants stop treating single diners as lepers!). Walls are covered with photos taken of diners and posters of K Pop stars-all very Seoul. The food was fantastic. We had crispy chilli squid, panko breaded prawns and some kimchi to start (I understand it's almost an insult not to have the latter!). All were excellent, the squid was crispy as promised and spicy. For mains we all bowed down to king Bibimbap. This bowl of lovelyness comes in a red hot stone bowl. I've never eaten anything before that remains hot to the last mouthful. And what a mouthful-full of flavour, I could have eaten another straight after. Service was youthful and friendly. We washed it all down with Hite beer. What are you waiting for?

photos.caption: Photo of Bibimbap - London, United Kingdom. The full monty
Photo of Bibimbap - London, United Kingdom. The said bibimbap. This is chicken
Photo of Bibimbap - London, United Kingdom. Monday night in Bibimbap

EVLeExshxidNEmlDVRp4nQ.text: Considering all the random things mashed up in it... should it taste good? For those of you who live under a rock, it's basically an assortment of toppings (veg, etc.) on a bed of rice in a hot stone pot. You can order a fried egg for a pound, to which hot sauce is then added, and then everything is mixed together. Looks absolutely revolting... tastes surprisingly good. Coming from someone who has no clue what bi bim bap SHOULD taste like, I thought it was delicious for £8.95. Although, it wasn't amazing.
